string: ACT I
SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
Enter VALENTINE and PROTEUS
VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Were't not affection chains thy tender days
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I rather would entreat thy company
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To see the wonders of the world abroad,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Than, living dully sluggardized at home,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Even as I would when I to love begin.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Wish me partaker in thy happiness
speaker: PROTEUS

string: When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: If ever danger do environ thee,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And on a love-book pray for my success?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: That's on some shallow story of deep love:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: That's a deep story of a deeper love:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: For he was more than over shoes in love.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And yet you never swum the Hellespont.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: What?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Coy looks with heart-sore sighs; one fading moment's mirth
speaker: VALENTINE

string: With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: If lost, why then a grievous labour won;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: However, but a folly bought with wit,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Or else a wit by folly vanquished.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Love is your master, for he masters you:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And he that is so yoked by a fool,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud
speaker: PROTEUS

string: The eating canker dwells, so eating love
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Inhabits in the finest wits of all.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And writers say, as the most forward bud
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Even so by love the young and tender wit
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Losing his verdure even in the prime
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And all the fair effects of future hopes.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: That art a votary to fond desire?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Once more adieu! my father at the road
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Of thy success in love, and what news else
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And likewise will visit thee with mine.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Exit
PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: He after honour hunts, I after love:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: He leaves his friends to dignify them more,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: War with good counsel, set the world at nought;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Enter SPEED
SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,
speaker: SPEED

string: And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: An if the shepherd be a while away.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,
speaker: SPEED

string: and I a sheep?
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I do.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: This proves me still a sheep.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: True; and thy master a shepherd.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the
speaker: SPEED

string: shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks
speaker: SPEED

string: not me: therefore I am no sheep.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the
speaker: PROTEUS

string: shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for
speaker: PROTEUS

string: wages followest thy master; thy master for wages
speaker: PROTEUS

string: follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her,
speaker: SPEED

string: a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a
speaker: SPEED

string: lost mutton, nothing for my labour.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for
speaker: SPEED

string: carrying your letter.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: You mistake; I mean the pound,--a pinfold.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,
speaker: SPEED

string: 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to
speaker: SPEED

string: your lover.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But what said she?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: [First nodding]  Ay.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you ask
speaker: SPEED

string: me if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And that set together is noddy.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Now you have taken the pains to set it together,
speaker: SPEED

string: take it for your pains.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Why sir, how do you bear with me?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothing
speaker: SPEED

string: but the word 'noddy' for my pains.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may
speaker: SPEED

string: be both at once delivered.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no,
speaker: SPEED

string: not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:
speaker: SPEED

string: and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I
speaker: SPEED

string: fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your
speaker: SPEED

string: mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as
speaker: SPEED

string: hard as steel.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: What said she? nothing?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SPEED
speaker: SPEED

string: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To
speaker: SPEED

string: testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned
speaker: SPEED

string: me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your
speaker: SPEED

string: letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.
speaker: SPEED

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Which cannot perish having thee aboard,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Being destined to a drier death on shore.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Exit SPEED
I must go send some better messenger:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Receiving them from such a worthless post.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Exit
SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
Enter JULlA and LUCETTA
JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,
speaker: JULIA

string: Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
speaker: JULIA

string: That every day with parle encounter me,
speaker: JULIA

string: In thy opinion which is worthiest love?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind
speaker: LUCETTA

string: According to my shallow simple skill.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;
speaker: LUCETTA

string: But, were I you, he never should be mine.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: How now! what means this passion at his name?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame
speaker: LUCETTA

string: That I, unworthy body as I am,
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Then thus: of many good I think him best.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Your reason?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: I have no other, but a woman's reason;
speaker: LUCETTA

string: I think him so because I think him so.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: His little speaking shows his love but small.
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: They do not love that do not show their love.
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: O, they love least that let men know their love.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: I would I knew his mind.
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Peruse this paper, madam.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: That the contents will show.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Say, say, who gave it thee?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: He would have given it you; but I, being in the way,
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Did in your name receive it: pardon the
speaker: LUCETTA

string: fault I pray.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!
speaker: JULIA

string: Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
speaker: JULIA

string: To whisper and conspire against my youth?
speaker: JULIA

string: Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth
speaker: JULIA

string: And you an officer fit for the place.
speaker: JULIA

string: Or else return no more into my sight.
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Will ye be gone?
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: That you may ruminate.
speaker: LUCETTA

string: Exit
JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:
speaker: JULIA

string: It were a shame to call her back again
speaker: JULIA

string: And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
speaker: JULIA

string: What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,
speaker: JULIA

string: And would not force the letter to my view!
speaker: JULIA

string: Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that
speaker: JULIA

string: Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
speaker: JULIA

string: Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love
speaker: JULIA

string: That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse
speaker: JULIA

string: And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
speaker: JULIA

string: How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,
speaker: JULIA

string: When willingly I would have had her here!
speaker: JULIA

string: How angerly I taught my brow to frown,
speaker: JULIA

string: When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!
speaker: JULIA

string: My penance is to call Lucetta back
speaker: JULIA

string: And ask remission for my folly past.
speaker: JULIA

string: What ho! Lucetta!
speaker: JULIA

LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: What would your ladyship?

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: I would it were,

speaker: LUCETTA

speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA

speaker: JULIA

speaker: LUCETTA

speaker: JULIA

string: LUCETTA
speaker: LUCETTA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

speaker: LUCETTA

speaker: JULIA

string: Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away
speaker: JULIA

speaker: PROTEUS

string: 'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: But when I look on her perfections,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: There is no reason but I shall be blind.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: If I can cheque my erring love, I will;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Exit

SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.

PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: At first I did adore a twinkling star,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But now I worship a celestial sun.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And he wants wit that wants resolved will
speaker: PROTEUS

string: To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But there I leave to love where I should love.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: If I lose them, thus find I by their loss
speaker: PROTEUS

string: For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I to myself am dearer than a friend,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: For love is still most precious in itself;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!--
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I will forget that Julia is alive,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Remembering that my love to her is dead;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I cannot now prove constant to myself,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Without some treachery used to Valentine.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
speaker: PROTEUS

string: To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Myself in counsel, his competitor.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Now presently I'll give her father notice
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Of their disguising and pretended flight;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross
speaker: PROTEUS

string: By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Exit

speaker: JULIA

speaker: DUKE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

speaker: PROTEUS

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

speaker: DUKE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Where your good word cannot advantage him,
speaker: DUKE

string: Your slander never can endamage him;
speaker: DUKE

speaker: DUKE

string: Being entreated to it by your friend.
speaker: DUKE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it
speaker: PROTEUS

string: By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: But say this weed her love from Valentine,
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: THURIO
speaker: THURIO

speaker: THURIO

string: Lest it should ravel and be good to none,
speaker: THURIO

speaker: THURIO

string: As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.
speaker: THURIO

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

speaker: DUKE

string: Because we know, on Valentine's report,
speaker: DUKE

string: You are already Love's firm votary
speaker: DUKE

string: And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
speaker: DUKE

speaker: DUKE

string: Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
speaker: DUKE

string: For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
speaker: DUKE

string: And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
speaker: DUKE

string: Where you may temper her by your persuasion
speaker: DUKE

string: To hate young Valentine and love my friend.
speaker: DUKE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: As much as I can do, I will effect:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: You must lay lime to tangle her desires
speaker: PROTEUS

string: By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Ay,
speaker: DUKE

string: Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.
speaker: DUKE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Say that upon the altar of her beauty
speaker: PROTEUS

string: You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

string: Moist it again, and frame some feeling line
speaker: PROTEUS

string: That may discover such integrity:
speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS

speaker: DUKE

speaker: THURIO

string: Enter DUKE
DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!
speaker: DUKE

string: Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?
speaker: DUKE

string: THURIO
speaker: THURIO

string: Not I.
speaker: THURIO

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Nor I.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Saw you my daughter?
speaker: DUKE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Neither.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Why then,
speaker: DUKE

string: She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;
speaker: DUKE

string: And Eglamour is in her company.
speaker: DUKE

string: 'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,
speaker: DUKE

string: As he in penance wander'd through the forest;
speaker: DUKE

string: Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,
speaker: DUKE

string: But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;
speaker: DUKE

string: Besides, she did intend confession
speaker: DUKE

string: At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;
speaker: DUKE

string: These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
speaker: DUKE

string: Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,
speaker: DUKE

string: But mount you presently and meet with me
speaker: DUKE

string: Upon the rising of the mountain-foot
speaker: DUKE

string: That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:
speaker: DUKE

string: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.
speaker: DUKE

string: Exit
THURIO
speaker: THURIO

string: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,
speaker: THURIO

string: That flies her fortune when it follows her.
speaker: THURIO

string: I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour
speaker: THURIO

string: Than for the love of reckless Silvia.
speaker: THURIO

string: Exit
PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Exit
JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: And I will follow, more to cross that love
speaker: JULIA

string: Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.
speaker: JULIA

string: Exit
SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
Enter Outlaws with SILVIA
First Outlaw
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Come, come,
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.
speaker: First Outlaw

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: A thousand more mischances than this one
speaker: SILVIA

string: Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.
speaker: SILVIA

string: Second Outlaw
speaker: Second Outlaw

string: Come, bring her away.
speaker: Second Outlaw

string: First Outlaw
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Where is the gentleman that was with her?
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Third Outlaw
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.
speaker: Third Outlaw

string: First Outlaw
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:
speaker: First Outlaw

string: Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,
speaker: First Outlaw

string: And will not use a woman lawlessly.
speaker: First Outlaw

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!
speaker: SILVIA

string: Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
Enter VALENTINE
VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And to the nightingale's complaining notes
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Tune my distresses and record my woes.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And leave no memory of what it was!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: These are my mates, that make their wills their law,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Have some unhappy passenger in chase.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: They love me well; yet I have much to do
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To keep them from uncivil outrages.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Enter PROTEUS, SILVIA, and JULIA
PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Madam, this service I have done for you,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Though you respect not aught your servant doth,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: To hazard life and rescue you from him
speaker: PROTEUS

string: That would have forced your honour and your love;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: A smaller boon than this I cannot beg
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: [Aside]  How like a dream is this I see and hear!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: O miserable, unhappy that I am!
speaker: SILVIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But by my coming I have made you happy.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.
speaker: SILVIA

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: [Aside]  And me, when he approacheth to your presence.
speaker: JULIA

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,
speaker: SILVIA

string: I would have been a breakfast to the beast,
speaker: SILVIA

string: Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
speaker: SILVIA

string: O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
speaker: SILVIA

string: Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!
speaker: SILVIA

string: And full as much, for more there cannot be,
speaker: SILVIA

string: I do detest false perjured Proteus.
speaker: SILVIA

string: Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.
speaker: SILVIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Would I not undergo for one calm look!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: When women cannot love where they're beloved!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.
speaker: SILVIA

string: Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,
speaker: SILVIA

string: For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith
speaker: SILVIA

string: Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths
speaker: SILVIA

string: Descended into perjury, to love me.
speaker: SILVIA

string: Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;
speaker: SILVIA

string: And that's far worse than none; better have none
speaker: SILVIA

string: Than plural faith which is too much by one:
speaker: SILVIA

string: Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!
speaker: SILVIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: In love
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Who respects friend?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: All men but Proteus.
speaker: SILVIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Can no way change you to a milder form,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: And love you 'gainst the nature of love,--force ye.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: SILVIA
speaker: SILVIA

string: O heaven!
speaker: SILVIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I'll force thee yield to my desire.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Thou friend of an ill fashion!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Valentine!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: For such is a friend now; treacherous man!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: 'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: My shame and guilt confounds me.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Be a sufficient ransom for offence,
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I tender 't here; I do as truly suffer
speaker: PROTEUS

string: As e'er I did commit.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Then I am paid;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And once again I do receive thee honest.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Who by repentance is not satisfied
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And, that my love may appear plain and free,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: O me unhappy!
speaker: JULIA

string: Swoons
PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Look to the boy.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Look up; speak.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring
speaker: JULIA

string: to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.
speaker: JULIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Where is that ring, boy?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Here 'tis; this is it.
speaker: JULIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: How! let me see:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:
speaker: JULIA

string: This is the ring you sent to Silvia.
speaker: JULIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart
speaker: PROTEUS

string: I gave this unto Julia.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: And Julia herself did give it me;
speaker: JULIA

string: And Julia herself hath brought it hither.
speaker: JULIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: How! Julia!
speaker: PROTEUS

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,
speaker: JULIA

string: And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.
speaker: JULIA

string: How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
speaker: JULIA

string: O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!
speaker: JULIA

string: Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me
speaker: JULIA

string: Such an immodest raiment, if shame live
speaker: JULIA

string: In a disguise of love:
speaker: JULIA

string: It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
speaker: JULIA

string: Women to change their shapes than men their minds.
speaker: JULIA

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Than men their minds! 'tis true.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: O heaven! were man
speaker: PROTEUS

string: But constant, he were perfect. That one error
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy
speaker: PROTEUS

string: More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?
speaker: PROTEUS

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Come, come, a hand from either:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Let me be blest to make this happy close;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: 'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: PROTEUS
speaker: PROTEUS

string: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.
speaker: PROTEUS

string: JULIA
speaker: JULIA

string: And I mine.
speaker: JULIA

string: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
Outlaws
speaker: Outlaws

string: A prize, a prize, a prize!
speaker: Outlaws

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Banished Valentine.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Sir Valentine!
speaker: DUKE

string: THURIO
speaker: THURIO

string: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.
speaker: THURIO

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Come not within the measure of my wrath;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Verona shall not hold thee. Here she stands;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Take but possession of her with a touch:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: THURIO
speaker: THURIO

string: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;
speaker: THURIO

string: I hold him but a fool that will endanger
speaker: THURIO

string: His body for a girl that loves him not:
speaker: THURIO

string: I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.
speaker: THURIO

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: The more degenerate and base art thou,
speaker: DUKE

string: To make such means for her as thou hast done
speaker: DUKE

string: And leave her on such slight conditions.
speaker: DUKE

string: Now, by the honour of my ancestry,
speaker: DUKE

string: I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
speaker: DUKE

string: And think thee worthy of an empress' love:
speaker: DUKE

string: Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
speaker: DUKE

string: Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
speaker: DUKE

string: Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,
speaker: DUKE

string: To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
speaker: DUKE

string: Thou art a gentleman and well derived;
speaker: DUKE

string: Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.
speaker: DUKE

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.
speaker: DUKE

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: These banish'd men that I have kept withal
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Are men endued with worthy qualities:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Forgive them what they have committed here
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And let them be recall'd from their exile:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: They are reformed, civil, full of good
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And fit for great employment, worthy lord.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:
speaker: DUKE

string: Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
speaker: DUKE

string: Come, let us go: we will include all jars
speaker: DUKE

string: With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.
speaker: DUKE

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold
speaker: VALENTINE

string: With our discourse to make your grace to smile.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: What think you of this page, my lord?
speaker: VALENTINE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.
speaker: DUKE

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: DUKE
speaker: DUKE

string: What mean you by that saying?
speaker: DUKE

string: VALENTINE
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,
speaker: VALENTINE

string: That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear
speaker: VALENTINE

string: The story of your loves discovered:
speaker: VALENTINE

string: That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;
speaker: VALENTINE

string: One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
speaker: VALENTINE

string: Exeunt
